intro: Carya ovata var. mexicana, commonly known as the Mexican hickory, is a deciduous tree native to central Mexico. It belongs to the walnut family (Juglandaceae) and is characterized by its compound leaves and edible nuts. The tree typically grows to a height of 10–20 meters, with a broad, rounded canopy. Its bark is gray and fissured, and it produces small, yellowish flowers in early spring. The nuts are encased in a thick, spiny husk and are an important food source for wildlife.
